Helper functions for metan

Source: vignettes/vignettes_helper.Rmd
vignettes_helper.Rmd

Getting started

library(metan)
library(cowplot) # used to arrange the graphics
library(kableExtra) # Used to make the tables
library(tidyverse)
# Function to make HTML tables
print_table = function(table){
  kable(table, "html", digits = 3) %>%
    kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive"),
                  font_size = 12)
}

Bind cross-validation objects

AMMI0 = cv_ammi(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, naxis = 0, nboot = 50, nrepval = 2)
AMMI2 = cv_ammi(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, naxis = 2, nboot = 50, nrepval = 2)
AMMI9 = cv_ammi(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, naxis = 9, nboot = 50, nrepval = 2)
AMMIF = cv_ammif(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, nboot = 50, nrepval = 2)
BLUP = cv_blup(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, nboot = 50, nrepval = 2)
bind1 = bind_cv(AMMI0, AMMI2, AMMI9)
bind2 = bind_cv(AMMI0, AMMI2, AMMI9, bind = "means")

Split a dataframe into subsets grouped by one or more factors

Group data and exclude all non-numeric variables

g1 = split_factors(data_ge, ENV)
is.split_factors(g1)
[1] TRUE

Group data and keep all original variables

g2 = split_factors(data_ge, ENV, GEN, keep_factors = TRUE)
print_table(g2[[1]])
ENV GEN REP GY HM
E1 G1 1 2.167 44.93
E1 G1 2 2.503 46.90
E1 G1 3 2.427 47.75

Group a data frame using all factor variables

g3 = as.split_factors(CO2)
names(g3)
 [1] "Qn1 / Quebec / nonchilled"      "Qn2 / Quebec / nonchilled"     
 [3] "Qn3 / Quebec / nonchilled"      "Qc1 / Quebec / chilled"        
 [5] "Qc3 / Quebec / chilled"         "Qc2 / Quebec / chilled"        
 [7] "Mn3 / Mississippi / nonchilled" "Mn2 / Mississippi / nonchilled"
 [9] "Mn1 / Mississippi / nonchilled" "Mc2 / Mississippi / chilled"   
[11] "Mc3 / Mississippi / chilled"    "Mc1 / Mississippi / chilled"

Make a symmetric matrix

m <- matrix(NA, 10, 10)
m[lower.tri(m)] <- 1:45
print_table(m)
NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
1 NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
2 10 NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
3 11 18 NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
4 12 19 25 NA NA NA NA NA NA
5 13 20 26 31 NA NA NA NA NA
6 14 21 27 32 36 NA NA NA NA
7 15 22 28 33 37 40 NA NA NA
8 16 23 29 34 38 41 43 NA NA
9 17 24 30 35 39 42 44 45 NA 
sym = make_sym(m)
print_table(sym)
NA 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9
1 NA 10 11 12 13 14 15 16 17
2 10 NA 18 19 20 21 22 23 24
3 11 18 NA 25 26 27 28 29 30
4 12 19 25 NA 31 32 33 34 35
5 13 20 26 31 NA 36 37 38 39
6 14 21 27 32 36 NA 40 41 42
7 15 22 28 33 37 40 NA 43 44
8 16 23 29 34 38 41 43 NA 45
9 17 24 30 35 39 42 44 45 NA

Generate pairwise combinations of variables by applying one function to each pair

data = data.frame(A = runif(n = 5, min = 3, max = 30),
                  B = runif(n = 5, min = 1, max = 10),
                  C = runif(n = 5, min = 9, max = 90),
                  D = runif(n = 5, min = 1, max = 90),
                  E = runif(n = 5, min = 5, max = 10))
c1 = comb_vars(data)
print_table(c1)
AxB AxC AxD AxE BxC BxD BxE CxD CxE DxE
29.534 58.748 44.272 31.202 44.013 29.537 16.467 58.751 45.681 31.205
8.309 50.715 86.344 13.704 45.706 81.335 8.695 123.741 51.102 86.730
29.864 112.561 90.041 32.731 92.126 69.606 12.296 152.303 94.993 72.473
30.228 73.801 75.763 30.240 58.734 60.696 15.174 104.270 58.747 60.709
31.094 101.194 33.954 30.069 83.781 16.541 12.656 86.641 82.756 15.516 
c2 = comb_vars(data, FUN = "*", order = "first")
print_table(c2)
AxB AxC AxD AxE BxC BxD BxE CxD CxE DxE
163.777 810.425 490.003 200.708 270.914 163.801 67.094 810.542 332.003 200.737
10.986 293.370 530.617 46.914 72.688 131.470 11.624 3510.632 310.387 561.394
118.558 2198.355 1631.987 190.673 412.069 305.906 35.740 5672.260 662.717 491.980
171.677 1158.484 1202.916 171.960 387.776 402.648 57.560 2717.085 388.414 403.311
165.905 1866.083 235.268 141.054 526.307 66.355 39.783 746.350 447.470 56.415

Combining data.frames by row, filling missing values

df1 = data.frame(v1 = c(1, 2), v2 = c(2, 3))
df2 = data.frame(v3 = c(4, 5))
rbind_fill(df1, df2)
  v1 v2 v3
1  1  2  .
2  2  3  .
3  .  .  4
4  .  .  5
rbind_fill(df1, df2, fill = "NA")
  v1 v2 v3
1  1  2 NA
2  2  3 NA
3 NA NA  4
4 NA NA  5

Rescale a continuous vector to have specified minimum and maximum values

Rescale a numeric vector

resca(values = c(1:5))
[1]   0  25  50  75 100

Rescale using a data frame and select rescaled variables only

data_ge %>%
resca(GY, HM, new_min = 0, new_max = 1,  keep = FALSE) %>%
  head()%>%
  print_table()
GY_res HM_res
0.338 0.346
0.414 0.445
0.397 0.487
0.574 0.360
0.512 0.365
0.428 0.375

Reescale within factors

  data_ge2 %>% 
    select(ENV, GEN, starts_with("N"), ends_with("L")) %>%
    group_by(ENV, GEN) %>%
    summarise_all(mean) %>%
    group_by(ENV) %>%
    resca(ends_with("L")) %>%
    head(n = 13) %>%
    print_table()
ENV GEN NR NKR NKE EL CL EL_res CL_res
A1 H1 16.267 33.267 526.933 15.433 28.055 34.397 25.011
A1 H10 16.667 31.200 515.400 16.100 31.367 69.858 81.750

A1 H5 14.533 37.400 538.800 15.760 28.311 51.773 29.408
A1 H6 16.800 35.533 568.533 16.667 31.696 100.000 87.392
